content: Conway's Game of Life is a zero player game, which means its evolution is determined by its initial state.
The idea behind it is to create an initial state and observe how it evolves.
There are rules that effect how the state evolves based off the status (alive or dead) of each cell.
This is just an exercise for me in problem solving and the fact that I've hosted it only stems from a narcissistic need to pat myself on the back; to you this is useless.

listItems: Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbours dies, as if by underpopulation.
Any live cell with two or three live neighbours lives on to the next generation.
Any live cell with more than three live neighbours dies, as if by overpopulation.
Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbours becomes a live cell, as if by reproduction.
Select a grid size between 8 and 75 (the size you choose affects the amount of cells in each row and column) and press enter.
Randomize your grid by clicking the 'Random Grid' button.
You can manually update your grid by clicking individual cells; this will toggle that cell's status between 'alive' and 'dead'.
Click 'Start' to watch the evolution of your grid and see where it ends up!
